rules: Rule1: Provided that Johnâ€™s test for influenza is accurate, it is not the case that John has a false positive for influenza.
Rule2: Whenever Mary is a carrier of influenza, Mary is asymptomatic for influenza.
Rule3: Either the influenza outbreak is contained, or influenza is a seasonal outbreak.
Rule4: Under the condition that a vaccine is available for influenza, the outbreak is not contained.
Rule5: A vaccine is available for influenza, or the community has herd immunity.
Rule6: Provided that John is symptomatic with influenza, John is infected with influenza.
Rule7: Either travel restrictions are in place for influenza, or social distancing measures are enforced for influenza.
Rule8: Under the condition that social distancing measures are enforced for influenza, influenza is not a pandemic.
Rule9: The community is under lockdown, or, if travel restrictions are in place for influenza, then influenza is not a pandemic.
Rule10: Whenever clinical trials are underway for influenza, research is ongoing for influenza.
Rule11: Clinical trials are underway for influenza, or drug development is proceeding for influenza.
Rule12: Under the condition that drug development is proceeding for influenza, an antiviral has been discovered for influenza.
Rule13: Provided that treatment is successful for influenza, there is no vaccine failure for influenza.
Rule14: If John has a fever, then John is symptomatic with influenza.

Rule15: Research funding has been cut, or, if it is not the case that an antiviral discovery implies that non-seasonal outbreak leads to treatment availability, then treatment is successful for influenza.
Rule16: Whenever influenza transmission has stopped, the outbreak is not contained.
Rule17: If the community is cooperating with public health measures, then, provided that the community has herd immunity, influenza transmission has stopped.
Rule18: The community is cooperating with public health measures, or the government is intervening in the community.
Rule19: Under the condition that the government is intervening in the community, if the community has herd immunity, then influenza transmission has stopped.
Rule20: Whenever surveillance is active in the community, contact tracing is being conducted in the community.
Rule21: Provided that contact tracing is being conducted in the community, testing is widespread in the community.
Rule22: Under the condition that testing is widespread in the community, early detection is occurring in the community.
Rule23: If early detection is occurring in the community, then, provided that either a mutation has not occurred or the outbreak is not contained, influenza is not vaccine-resistant.
Rule24: If John has a cough, then John has a fever.

Rule25: If WHO has issued alerts for influenza, then, under the condition that there is no international cooperation or no ongoing research or non-seasonal outbreak implies treatment availability, influenza has not spread globally.
Rule26: WHO has issued alerts for influenza, or the CDC is responding to influenza.
Rule27: If the CDC is responding to influenza, then emergency funds are allocated for influenza.

Rule28: Under the condition that emergency funds are allocated for influenza, if there is no international cooperation or no ongoing research or non-seasonal outbreak implies treatment availability, then influenza has not spread globally.

Rule29: If there has been a scientific breakthrough for influenza, then, under the condition that it is not the case that an antiviral discovery implies that non-seasonal outbreak leads to treatment availability, treatment is successful for influenza.
Rule30: Provided that the research is peer-reviewed, if medical research is being conducted on influenza, then there has been a scientific breakthrough for influenza.
Rule31: If preliminary findings have been released for the research, then, whenever medical research is being conducted on influenza, there has been a scientific breakthrough for influenza.
Rule32: The study is published, or a preprint is available for the research.
Rule33: If a preprint is available for the research, then preliminary findings have been released for the research.
Rule34: Provided that phase 1 of the trials is complete, if drug development is proceeding for influenza, then, whenever influenza is not a seasonal outbreak, a treatment is available for influenza.

Rule35: If phase 2 of the trials is complete, then, under the condition that drug development is proceeding for influenza, provided that influenza is not a seasonal outbreak, a treatment is available for influenza.
Rule36: Whenever the treatment has emergency authorization, the treatment is FDA-approved.
Rule37: The treatment has been recalled, or the treatment is safe, or the treatment does not have side effects.
Rule38: If an alternative treatment exists for influenza, then the treatment has not been recalled.
Rule39: An alternative treatment exists for influenza, or a traditional remedy is used for influenza.
Rule40: Provided that a traditional remedy is used for influenza, the treatment has not been recalled.
Rule41: John tested positive for influenza, or John is a confirmed case of influenza.
Rule42: If John is a confirmed case of influenza, then, under the condition that it is not the case that non-seasonal outbreak leads to quarantine implies hospitalization, John has recovered.
Rule43: Provided that it is not the case that Mary being contagious implies she was not exposed, Mary is a carrier of influenza.
Rule44: If it is not the case that herd immunity implies the outbreak is not contained, then influenza is a pandemic.
Rule45: Under the condition that it is not the case that an antiviral discovery implies that non-seasonal outbreak leads to treatment availability, there is vaccine failure for influenza.
Rule46: Provided that it is not the case that either a mutation has occurred or the outbreak is not contained, influenza is vaccine-resistant.
Rule47: Under the condition that it is not the case that there is international cooperation or ongoing research or non-seasonal outbreak implies treatment availability, influenza has spread globally.
Rule48: If it is not the case that the study being published implies it is peer-reviewed, then the study has been retracted.
Rule49: Provided that it is not the case that the study being published implies it is peer-reviewed, the study has not been retracted.

Rule50: Provided that it is not the case that John testing positive implies that non-quarantine due to non-seasonal outbreak implies hospitalization leads to recovery, John has a false positive for influenza.

Rule51: If it is not the case that John testing positive implies that non-quarantine due to non-seasonal outbreak implies hospitalization leads to recovery, then John's test for influenza was accurate.
Rule52: If it is not the case that non-completion of phase 1 or phase 2 implies emergency authorization, then the treatment has side effects.
Rule53: If it is not the case that non-quarantine due to non-seasonal outbreak implies hospitalization, then John has not recovered.
Rule54: If it is not the case that non-seasonal outbreak leads to quarantine, then John is not hospitalized.
Rule55: Provided that influenza is not a seasonal outbreak, Mary was exposed to influenza.
Rule56: If influenza is not a seasonal outbreak, then Mary is contagious with influenza.
Rule57: Whenever influenza is not a seasonal outbreak, John has a cough.
Rule58: Provided that influenza is not a seasonal outbreak, a treatment is not available for influenza.
facts: Fact1: Surveillance is active in the community.
Fact2: Medical research is being conducted on influenza.
Fact3: It is not the case that John is infected with influenza.
Fact4: Mary is not asymptomatic for influenza.
Fact5: The community is not under lockdown.
Fact6: Research is not ongoing for influenza.
Fact7: Research funding has not been cut.
Fact8: A mutation has not occurred in influenza.
Fact9: There is no international cooperation for influenza.
Fact11: The treatment is not FDA-approved.
Fact12: The treatment is not safe.
